M.G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to M.G.L. c. 212, § 3, as the matter in controversy exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interest and costs.

M.G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to M.G.L. c. 223, § 1, because the events giving rise to this action occurred in Middlesex County, Massachusetts.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a lawful invitee, a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain its premises in a safe condition, to warn of any dangerous conditions, and to promptly remedy such conditions.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a concurrence focused on abolishing the invitee/licensee distinction and questioning the continued separate treatment of trespassers. It does not set out or affirm the specific, traditional invitee-duty formulation (reasonable care to keep premises safe, warn, and remedy dangers) referenced in the proposition. While the full Mounsey opinion addresses occupier duties broadly, nothing in this quoted text clearly articulates the claimed invitee duty, so this specific excerpt does not support the proposition as stated.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential."

*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.raw_text: *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165, 166-67 (1973).
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.proposition: Defendant breached this duty by failing to clean up the spilled milk in a timely manner or provide adequate warnings, despite having actual knowledge of the hazardous condition.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses a premises owner's duty to use due care to keep premises reasonably safe or warn of dangers, but it does not involve spilled milk, actual knowledge of the hazard, or a failure to clean up after such knowledge. Instead, the court holds that the evidence was insufficient to infer that the defendant knew or should have known of the unidentified substance in time to remedy it, and it orders judgment for the defendant. Thus, the case does not support the proposition that the defendant breached its duty by failing to clean up a spill despite actual knowledge of it.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.relevant_excerpt: “Where a foreign substance on a floor or stairway causes the business visitor to fall and sustain injuries, he may prove the negligence of the defendant by proof that the defendant or his servant caused the substance to be there, or he may show that the defendant or his servants had actual knowledge of the existence of the foreign substance… In the more usual case, however, the plaintiff attempts to establish the defendant’s negligence by showing that the foreign substance was present… for such a length of time that the defendant should have known about it.”

See *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets.raw_text: See *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780, 783-84 (2007).
See *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets.proposition: Failure to act promptly in addressing a known hazard constitutes negligence.
See *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
See *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets.support_reasoning: The case focuses on when a store is deemed to have notice of hazards inherent in its self-service mode of operation and adopts the mode-of-operation approach to premises liability. It does not discuss the timing of a defendant’s response after it becomes aware of a specific, existing hazard, nor does it hold that failure to act *promptly* upon known hazards constitutes negligence. The opinion is about imputing notice from the nature of operations, not about delay in remedying a hazard once known.
See *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets.relevant_excerpt: Additionally, a store owner will be liable to a plaintiff injured as a result of a dangerous condition caused by a third party only if the owner could reasonably foresee that the dangerous condition could occur, resulting from the owner’s chosen mode of operation, and the owner took inadequate steps to forestall resulting injuries. … [T]he trier of fact [must] determine whether the owner could reasonably foresee or anticipate that a foreseeable risk stemming from the owner’s mode of operation could occur and whether the owner exercised reasonable care in maintaining the premise in a safe condition commensurate with these foreseeable risks.

*Goddard v. Boston & Maine R.R.*, 179 Ma.proposition: The presence of cart tracks through the puddle indicates the condition had existed long enough that Defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have discovered and remedied it.
*Goddard v. Boston & Maine R.R.*, 179 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt does not address cart tracks, puddles, or the inference that visible track marks show a condition existed long enough for discovery and remediation. Instead, Holmes, C.J. emphasizes that the banana peel might have been dropped within a minute, underscoring the lack of evidence of duration. The case therefore does not support the claimed proposition and in fact points in the opposite direction on the temporal-notice issue.
*Goddard v. Boston & Maine R.R.*, 179 Ma.relevant_excerpt: "The banana skin upon which the plaintiff stepped and which caused him to slip may have been dropped within a minute by one of the persons who was leaving the train. It is unnecessary to go further to decide the case."

*Colter v. Barber-Greene Co.*, 403 Mass..proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff sustained injuries, economic losses, and other damages.
*Colter v. Barber-Greene Co.*, 403 Mass..support_reasoning: The case discusses proximate cause in the context of product design negligence and warranty, but it does not articulate or endorse the generic pleading-style proposition that, “As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff sustained injuries, economic losses, and other damages.” Instead, it evaluates whether there was sufficient evidence that negligent design was a proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries and whether the plaintiff’s conduct barred recovery. The opinion is about standards for proving proximate causation and comparative fault, not about establishing that such a conclusory causal allegation is correct in this particular case.
*Colter v. Barber-Greene Co.*, 403 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “To withstand a motion for a directed verdict on the issue of proximate causation, the plaintiff need only demonstrate that there was a greater likelihood that the harm of which the plaintiff complains was due to causes for which the defendant was responsible. The plaintiff need not eliminate all possibility that the defendant's conduct was not a cause, but need only introduce evidence from which reasonable jurors could conclude that it was more probable than not that the injuries were caused by the defendant's conduct.” (403 Mass. at 54-55.)

*Donovan v. Johnson, Inc.*, 295 Mass. 17.proposition: Defendant’s conduct was a substantial factor in causing Plaintiff’s injuries.
*Donovan v. Johnson, Inc.*, 295 Mass. 17.support_reasoning: The opinion is an insurance contract case focused on misrepresentations in an application and statutory requirements for attaching a correct copy of the application to the policy. It does not analyze causation in tort or discuss whether a defendant’s conduct was a substantial factor in causing a plaintiff’s injuries. Therefore, it provides no authority for the claimed substantial-factor causation proposition.
*Donovan v. Johnson, Inc.*, 295 Mass. 17.relevant_excerpt: It is provided by G. L. (Ter. Ed.) c. 175, § 186, that "No oral or written misrepresentation or warranty made in the negotiation of a policy of insurance by the insured or in his behalf shall be deemed material or defeat or avoid the policy or prevent its attaching unless such misrepresentation or warranty is made with actual intent to deceive or unless the matter misrepresented or made a warranty increased the risk of loss."
